linkTarget.anchoringText: Grimbeek II field is a multilayer heterogeneous fluvial reservoir producing from Trebol formation which is part of the Comodoro Rivadavia Group (Hechem 1998, Paredes et al. 2007). The project targets three main stratigraphic sequences (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Cross section through an incised valley that connects one of the polymer injectors (GBK-980) with the confined polymer pilot producer (GBK-643). The figure shows the internal geometry of the high resolution well correlations. The pilot reservoir zone comprises connected point bar sandstones in a background of floodplain. The filling in the fluvial channel comprises a complex labyrinth of point bars and clay plugs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section through an incised valley that connects one of the polymer injectors (GBK-980) with the confined polymer pilot producer (GBK-643). The figure shows the internal geometry of the high resolution well correlations. The pilot reservoir zone comprises connected point bar sandstones in a background of floodplain. The filling in the fluvial channel comprises a complex labyrinth of point bars and clay plugs.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Grimbeek II field is a multilayer heterogeneous fluvial reservoir producing from Trebol formation which is part of the Comodoro Rivadavia Group (Hechem 1998, Paredes et al. 2007). The project targets three main stratigraphic sequences (Figure 1). The top interval is unconsolidated and had been lost in the majority of the cores. We have been able to run corefloods in the reservoir material from the two bottom intervals (Figure 1) that are more consolidated but still friable (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Core material recovered from coring.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core material recovered from coring.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir study is one of the key tasks in any EOR project. Historically, most field projects have failed because insufficient understanding of the reservoir. In order to fully understand the reservoir and being able to interpret the results, one should start with a geological-dynamic model, followed by a review of production history, and the execution of some field inter-well tracer tests, transient tests and saturation logging. It is very important to conduct an integrated and detailed reservoir studies through a joint effort of geoscientists/reservoir/production/operations engineers. We constructed two 3D models of a very heterogeneous low net-to-gross fluvial reservoir at two scales (Figure 3 and Figure 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Cross section in the pilot zone. a) Pilot sector model at fine scale sequence stratigraphic correlation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section in the pilot zone. a) Pilot sector model at fine scale sequence stratigraphic correlation

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir study is one of the key tasks in any EOR project. Historically, most field projects have failed because insufficient understanding of the reservoir. In order to fully understand the reservoir and being able to interpret the results, one should start with a geological-dynamic model, followed by a review of production history, and the execution of some field inter-well tracer tests, transient tests and saturation logging. It is very important to conduct an integrated and detailed reservoir studies through a joint effort of geoscientists/reservoir/production/operations engineers. We constructed two 3D models of a very heterogeneous low net-to-gross fluvial reservoir at two scales (Figure 3 and Figure 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: The same cross section as in Figure 3 but in the coarse scale model. The warm colours represent high values of porosity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The same cross section as in Figure 3 but in the coarse scale model. The warm colours represent high values of porosity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: After injecting less than 0.15 pore volumes of 2500/3000ppm polymer we recovered 11% ooip incremental oil above waterflooding from the central pattern (Figure 16b) and 6.2% of the ooip from offset producers in contacted zone (Figure 16c). The water cut reduced from 90% to 45% in the confined producer and from 87% to 67% in the nine offset producers (Figure 14b). Water cut reduction is greater than best pilots in the literature (Figure 14b). This can be explained because of the cross flow between fluvial layers in the inter-well region showing very good vertical connectivity (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Grimbeek reservoir architecture is a confined system. The 3D models capture the amalgamate of different deposits that were eroded by new density paleo river flows. The system confinement made possible the amalgamation which is a reservoir architecture with very good vertical connectivity (vertical permeability).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Grimbeek reservoir architecture is a confined system. The 3D models capture the amalgamate of different deposits that were eroded by new density paleo river flows. The system confinement made possible the amalgamation which is a reservoir architecture with very good vertical connectivity (vertical permeability).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Â

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Full-field model. a) Fence in the pilot zone showing in warm colours the channel bars of high porosity and permeability. b) Plan view of the pilot zone divided in three regions that are affected by the polymer injection in the four wells. The confined well zone green, the offset producers zone brown and the second group of producers red.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Full-field model. a) Fence in the pilot zone showing in warm colours the channel bars of high porosity and permeability. b) Plan view of the pilot zone divided in three regions that are affected by the polymer injection in the four wells. The confined well zone green, the offset producers zone brown and the second group of producers red.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Fence in the pilot zone showing in warm colours the channel bars of high porosity and permeability
Plan view of the pilot zone divided in three regions that are affected by the polymer injection in the four wells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: At the beginning of the water injection, the field was heavily depleted below bubble point; the pressure was 60% below the initial pressure. We injected water prior to the polymer injection for a period of three years until waterflooding baseline was established at 100 m3/day per injector well. Prior to polymer injection, injectors were evaluated for injection profile (time lapse saturation logging). In the pilot area, there are 10 producers and 4 polymer injector (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Well profiles of the four polymer injectors in the pilot. The first two well from left to right have three intervals the other two have four intervals but the bottom intervals are interconnected in the interwell zone. There are four tracks in each well profile. Well perforations, transmissivity factor, effective cell thickness and horizontal permeability.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well profiles of the four polymer injectors in the pilot. The first two well from left to right have three intervals the other two have four intervals but the bottom intervals are interconnected in the interwell zone. There are four tracks in each well profile. Well perforations, transmissivity factor, effective cell thickness and horizontal permeability.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 8 shows a permanent installation for water treatment, polymer dispersion and injection. This facility is installed 2 km away of the pilot zone. Notice the water treatment facilities (flotation unit). The polymer processing units and the bulk bag handling systems is shown in Figure 8b.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Pilot facilities. a) Schematic representation of the processes and equipment water treatment and tanks). b) Polymer dispersion unit and maturation tanks. c) Monitoring and control of all processes and variable. d) Dedicated triplex injection for each well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pilot facilities. a) Schematic representation of the processes and equipment water treatment and tanks). b) Polymer dispersion unit and maturation tanks. c) Monitoring and control of all processes and variable. d) Dedicated triplex injection for each well.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Schematic representation of the processes and equipment water treatment and tanks).
Polymer dispersion unit and maturation tanks.
Monitoring and control of all processes and variable.
Dedicated triplex injection for each well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results for waterflooding particle swarm optimisation assisted history matching (histograms along the diagonal Figure 9) of the models at different scales revealed the water relative permeability end point was 0.25 to 0.3 for the best reservoir quality facies (Rock Type 5), which is the high permeability unconsolidated channel bar facies in the reservoir simulation models. For the other rock types, the water relative permeability end points were below 0.1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Scatter plot matrix of water relative permeability end points for each rock type using the particle swarm optimisation algorithm for the history matching. a) Coarse scale full-field model. b) Pilot sector model fine scale. This plot shows the correlations between parameters and in the diagonal the marginal distribution of each parameter. The features a) and b) are similar even the models have different simulation scale.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Scatter plot matrix of water relative permeability end points for each rock type using the particle swarm optimisation algorithm for the history matching. a) Coarse scale full-field model. b) Pilot sector model fine scale. This plot shows the correlations between parameters and in the diagonal the marginal distribution of each parameter. The features a) and b) are similar even the models have different simulation scale.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Coarse scale full-field model.
Pilot sector model fine scale.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The waterflooding response (oil rate increasing Figure 11b) seems more related to the water end point relative permeability measured on coreflood in the more consolidated reservoir material <0.1 (Figure 10). However, greater water relative permeability end points >0.2 matched better the oil rate decline (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Coreflood relative permeabilities measured in the plugs recovered from the core for more consolidated levels bottom intervals in Figure 7. The particle swarm optimisation algorithm (PSO) showed that unconsolidated faciesrock type 5) for which we could not run corefloods tend to have greater water relative permeability end point also oil relative permeability has a lower corey exponent.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Coreflood relative permeabilities measured in the plugs recovered from the core for more consolidated levels bottom intervals in Figure 7. The particle swarm optimisation algorithm (PSO) showed that unconsolidated faciesrock type 5) for which we could not run corefloods tend to have greater water relative permeability end point also oil relative permeability has a lower corey exponent.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The waterflooding response (oil rate increasing Figure 11b) seems more related to the water end point relative permeability measured on coreflood in the more consolidated reservoir material <0.1 (Figure 10). However, greater water relative permeability end points >0.2 matched better the oil rate decline (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Different stages in the waterflooding response, the black line is the data and coloured lines are two history matching cases. a) >0.2 water relative permeability end points produce poor matching at the early waterflooding response. b) <0.1 water relative permeability end points produce better matching at the early waterflooding response but overestimate the declining stage of the recovery process.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Different stages in the waterflooding response, the black line is the data and coloured lines are two history matching cases. a) >0.2 water relative permeability end points produce poor matching at the early waterflooding response. b) <0.1 water relative permeability end points produce better matching at the early waterflooding response but overestimate the declining stage of the recovery process.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: >0.2 water relative permeability end points produce poor matching at the early waterflooding response.
<0.1 water relative permeability end points produce better matching at the early waterflooding response but overestimate the declining stage of the recovery process.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The waterflooding baseline exposed the connectivity between injectors and producers (Figure 12). The streamlines display the heterogeneity, because the permeability differential between the components of the fluvial system, channels bars lateral accretion surfaces, over-bank deposits (Figure 12 orange colour).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Effect of the reservoir architecture in the flow paths for the pilot zone. Warm colors indicate high permeability. The wells located in the centre channel bars dominate the flow.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effect of the reservoir architecture in the flow paths for the pilot zone. Warm colors indicate high permeability. The wells located in the centre channel bars dominate the flow.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 13 shows that difference between patterns affected by polymer injection and waterflooding patterns becomes very noticeable. The average behaviour of the patterns affected by the four polymer injectors shows a clear decrease in the water/oil ratio when injected only 0.05 pore volumes of polymer solution compared to steady increase in the water/oil ratio as waterflooding advances.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Monitoring patterns affected by polymer by Water oil ratio RAP) versus injected pore volumes in the pattern. a) Map of the patterns affected by polymer injection polymer injectors at are the centre of the pattern. b) Clear reduction in RAP in the patterns affected by the polymer injection. c) All the patterns under waterflooding recovery. d) Typical RAP increase during a waterflooding recovery process.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Monitoring patterns affected by polymer by Water oil ratio RAP) versus injected pore volumes in the pattern. a) Map of the patterns affected by polymer injection polymer injectors at are the centre of the pattern. b) Clear reduction in RAP in the patterns affected by the polymer injection. c) All the patterns under waterflooding recovery. d) Typical RAP increase during a waterflooding recovery process.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Map of the patterns affected by polymer injection polymer injectors at are the centre of the pattern.
Clear reduction in RAP in the patterns affected by the polymer injection.
All the patterns under waterflooding recovery.
Typical RAP increase during a waterflooding recovery process.

linkTarget.anchoringText: After injecting less than 0.15 pore volumes of 2500/3000ppm polymer we recovered 11% ooip incremental oil above waterflooding from the central pattern (Figure 16b) and 6.2% of the ooip from offset producers in contacted zone (Figure 16c). The water cut reduced from 90% to 45% in the confined producer and from 87% to 67% in the nine offset producers (Figure 14b). Water cut reduction is greater than best pilots in the literature (Figure 14b). This can be explained because of the cross flow between fluvial layers in the inter-well region showing very good vertical connectivity (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: a) Incremental oil rate for the ten producers affected by the polymer injecting. b) Water cut reversal for the ten producers benchmarking with three monolayer pilots in Daqing

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Incremental oil rate for the ten producers affected by the polymer injecting. b) Water cut reversal for the ten producers benchmarking with three monolayer pilots in Daqing

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Incremental oil rate for the ten producers affected by the polymer injecting.
Water cut reversal for the ten producers benchmarking with three monolayer pilots in Daqing

linkTarget.anchoringText: Because it helps to understand the reservoir and interpret the results. Moreover, it is a tool to conceptualise multiple strategies. The utility factor of the pilot is 2.9 kg per incremental barrel of oil above waterflooding (Figure 15) which indicates in combination with the water cut curve that the project could still improve (decrease the utility factor). Also, the utility factor is a technical criteria for monitoring and optimisation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: size versus utility factor (Incremental oil bbl. per kg of polymer)

formatted-caption.caption-text: size versus utility factor (Incremental oil bbl. per kg of polymer)

linkTarget.anchoringText: After injecting less than 0.15 pore volumes of 2500/3000ppm polymer we recovered 11% ooip incremental oil above waterflooding from the central pattern (Figure 16b) and 6.2% of the ooip from offset producers in contacted zone (Figure 16c). The water cut reduced from 90% to 45% in the confined producer and from 87% to 67% in the nine offset producers (Figure 14b). Water cut reduction is greater than best pilots in the literature (Figure 14b). This can be explained because of the cross flow between fluvial layers in the inter-well region showing very good vertical connectivity (Figure 5).

linkTarget.anchoringText: After three to four months from the start of polymer injection the injectivity index changed the declining trend indicating that injectivity improved even injecting a fluid with a much more greater viscosity. This means that the effective injection thickness was increasing (profile modification) (Figure 17a, b, c, d).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Injectivity index Eq.1). a) Gbk-980. b) Gbk-981 c) Gbk-982 d) Gbk-993

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injectivity index Eq.1). a) Gbk-980. b) Gbk-981 c) Gbk-982 d) Gbk-993

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Gbk-981
Gbk-982
Gbk-993

linkTarget.anchoringText: We calculated water flow velocities across all cell faces for the three simulation models at two reservoir scales (pilot sector model coarse scale, pilot sector model fine scale and full-field model coarse scale). Figure 18a shows the cumulative distribution function of water flow velocities of all cells for each model, the vertical line shows the water velocity of 1 ft/day.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: a) Cumulative distribution function of water flow velocity from three simulations models Pilot sector model coarse scale, full field model and pilot sector model fine scale. b) Resistance factor rheology, more than 80% of the cells in the reservoir simulations models have water flow velocities across their faces that are associated to the Newtonian regime plateau).

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Cumulative distribution function of water flow velocity from three simulations models Pilot sector model coarse scale, full field model and pilot sector model fine scale. b) Resistance factor rheology, more than 80% of the cells in the reservoir simulations models have water flow velocities across their faces that are associated to the Newtonian regime plateau).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Cumulative distribution function of water flow velocity from three simulations models Pilot sector model coarse scale, full field model and pilot sector model fine scale.
Resistance factor rheology, more than 80% of the cells in the reservoir simulations models have water flow velocities across their faces that are associated to the Newtonian regime plateau).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 19 displays the reservoir simulation prediction using polymer resistance factor for the plateau regime and newtonian model for polymer resistance factor in each cell. The simulation underpredict the oil rate however the predictions are accurate, free from numerical instabilities and convergence problems that lead to wrong numerical solutions in many EOR simulations when including shearthinning and shearthickening rheology models and erroneous newtonian viscosity as assuming newtonian viscosity equal to laboratory measurements at 1 ft/day. Note that, just after polymer injection started we increased the production regime in the confined well; the water cut increased immediately and demonstrated the predictivity of the simulation model (Figure 19b). Then, the polymer response was well capture, oil rate raised and water rate declined even when increasing the gross rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Simulation solid line) versus data filled circles). a) Oil rate in the confined well. b) Water rate in the confined well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulation solid line) versus data filled circles). a) Oil rate in the confined well. b) Water rate in the confined well.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil rate in the confined well.
Water rate in the confined well.
